title: More than £77k worth of gold discovered beneath seat on Air India flight
title_page: More than £77k worth of gold discovered beneath seat on Air India flight | Daily Mail Online
text:
More than 7.5million rupees (£77,000) worth of gold has reportedly been discovered hidden beneath a seat on a flight.
Custom officials found almost seven pounds worth of the yellow metal on an Air India flight, which landed at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport in Shamshabad, India, yesterday, local media reports.
Based on a tip-off, staff searched the aircraft, which had landed following a flight from Dubai, and discovered the expensive metal.
Custom officials found almost seven pounds worth of the yellow metal on an Air India flight, local media reports
The bars of gold had been allegedly concealed behind a pipe beneath a seat in the cabin.
The New Indian Express claimed that the incident is the fifth case of its kind to take place in the last six weeks after flying this route, with two incidents in January and three in December.
So far, more than 22 pounds worth of abandoned gold is said to have been discovered.
The bars of gold had been allegedly concealed behind a pipe beneath a seat in the cabin (stock image)
Speaking to the New Indian Express, an airport official said: 'We recovered 3.1 kg from AI-952 which arrived at 9am at Shamshabad. It was found abandoned and hence no arrest.
'In flights, there would be a hollow pipe which supports the three seats.
'The window side of the pipe is usually open and gold biscuits are kept inside that for the next passenger to locate and retrieve.'
